verses.text: This is the word that came from the LORD: Go down to the house of the king of Judah and speak this word there:
verses.comment: Jeremiah receives direct instruction from the LORD to address the royal house. This establishes the role of prophets as mediators of God's message and foreshadows the importance of apostolic authority in the New Covenant.

verses.text: Say, 'Hear the word of the LORD, O king of Judah, who sits on David’s throne, you, your servants, and your people who enter these gates.'
verses.comment: The king is addressed as the rightful heir to David's throne, recalling the Davidic covenant and connecting to messianic expectations, ultimately fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: This is what the LORD says: Practice justice and righteousness, and deliver the robbed from the hand of the oppressor. Do no wrong, do no violence to the foreigner, the fatherless, or the widow, nor shed innocent blood in this place.
verses.comment: God commands concrete acts of justice and mercy, foreshadowing Christ’s teachings on love for the marginalized and the Church's historical emphasis on charity.

verses.text: For if you truly do this, then kings sitting on David’s throne, riding in chariots and on horses, will enter through these gates, they, their servants, and their people.
verses.comment: Obedience will ensure continuity of Davidic rule, strengthening the biblical theme of an enduring, visible kingdom set by God. Prefigures the concept of a visible Church governing in truth.

verses.text: But if you will not heed these words, I swear by Myself, declares the LORD, that this house will become a ruin.
verses.comment: God’s personal oath highlights the seriousness of judgment for disobedience, emphasizing divine justice and foreshadowing the consequences of apostasy and schism.

verses.text: For this is what the LORD says about the house of the king of Judah: You are like Gilead to Me, the summit of Lebanon; yet I will surely make you a desert, cities uninhabited.
verses.comment: Gilead and Lebanon symbolize beauty and strength, but God's judgment can turn blessing into desolation—reminding us that grace depends on faithful response.

verses.text: I will prepare destroyers against you, each with his weapons. They will cut down your choice cedars and cast them into the fire.
verses.comment: The image of destroyers cutting the cedars anticipates both the Babylonian conquest and a spiritual warning against pride in earthly splendor.

verses.text: Many nations will pass by this city, and each will say to another, 'Why has the LORD done this to this great city?'
verses.comment: Other nations are witnesses to Judah’s downfall, highlighting the global consequences of covenant fidelity and failure. This foreshadows the Church’s universal witness.

verses.text: And they will answer, 'Because they abandoned the covenant of the LORD their God and worshiped other gods and served them.'
verses.comment: The breaking of the covenant results in punishment, reinforcing the necessity of faithful worship and doctrinal purity, themes central to the sacramental life.

verses.text: Do not weep for the dead, nor mourn for him; but weep bitterly for the one who goes away, for he will never return or see his native land.
verses.comment: Emphasis is not on those who die, but on exile—a spiritual warning about separation from the community of faith.

verses.text: For this is what the LORD says about Shallum the son of Josiah, king of Judah, who succeeded Josiah his father, and who went away from this place: He will never return here.
verses.comment: Shallum (Jehoahaz) is judged, showing the consequences of unfaithfulness in leadership.

verses.text: For he will die in the place where they have led him captive; he will never see this land again.
verses.comment: The king’s exile and death in a foreign land signifies that separation from the holy city is grave—spiritually linked to separation from God’s covenant family.

verses.text: Woe to him who builds his house by injustice, and his rooms by wrongdoing, who makes his neighbor serve him for nothing and does not give him his wages.
verses.comment: Social justice is a repeated expectation, connecting communal ethics with righteousness—mirrored in the communal life and works of mercy.

verses.text: He says, 'I will build myself a grand house with spacious upper rooms,' cuts out windows for it, panels it with cedar, and paints it with bright red.
verses.comment: Condemnation of self-indulgence; true greatness comes from humility and service, echoing Christ’s example of poverty and self-giving.

verses.text: Do you think you are a king because you compete in cedar? Did not your father eat and drink and do justice and righteousness? Then it was well with him.
verses.comment: The true measure of kingship is not luxury but justice, a principle foundational to biblical definitions of leadership.

verses.text: He judged the cause of the poor and needy; then it was well. Is this not to know Me? says the LORD.
verses.comment: God equates care for the poor with true knowledge of Him, emphasizing the link between faith and works.

verses.text: But your eyes and your heart are set only on dishonest gain, on shedding innocent blood, and on doing oppression and violence.
verses.comment: Personal sin leads to social injustice, demonstrating how private morality has communal consequences.

verses.text: Therefore this is what the LORD says about Jehoiakim son of Josiah, king of Judah: They will not lament for him, saying, 'Alas, my brother!' or 'Alas, my sister!' They will not lament for him, saying, 'Alas, lord!' or 'Alas, his glory!'
verses.comment: Jehoiakim’s dishonor in death contrasts with the respect due the righteous, hinting at the eternal consequences of one’s choices.

verses.text: He will be buried with the burial of a donkey—dragged away and thrown outside the gates of Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The disgraceful burial symbolizes total rejection, reminiscent of language about being cut off from the people of God.

verses.text: Go up to Lebanon and cry out, and lift up your voice in Bashan; cry from Abarim, for all your lovers are destroyed.
verses.comment: Symbolic lament extends to Judah’s allies; spiritual betrayal leads to utter isolation.

verses.text: I spoke to you in your prosperity, but you said, 'I will not listen.' This has been your way since your youth—that you did not obey My voice.
verses.comment: Repeated refusal to listen in times of prosperity reveals the danger of spiritual complacency.

verses.text: The wind will shepherd all your shepherds, and your lovers will go into captivity. Then you will be ashamed and confounded because of all your wickedness.
verses.comment: A metaphor for spiritual leaders being scattered; illustrates the need for steadfast, divinely-instituted governance to prevent confusion.

verses.text: You who dwell in Lebanon, nestled in your cedar, how you will groan when pangs come upon you, agony like that of a woman in labor.
verses.comment: Sudden suffering likened to labor pains—a biblical motif also used for tribulation before deliverance or new creation.

verses.text: As surely as I live, declares the LORD, though Coniah son of Jehoiakim, king of Judah, were the signet ring on My right hand, I would tear you off.
verses.comment: Coniah (Jehoiachin) is disowned; signet ring imagery signals removal of authority, echoing the theme of legitimate succession and authority.

verses.text: I will give you into the hand of those who seek your life, into the hand of those whose face you fear—even into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon and into the hand of the Chaldeans.
verses.comment: Exile under Babylon is God's judgment; Nebuchadnezzar functions as an instrument of divine chastisement.

verses.text: I will cast you out, you and your mother who bore you, into another country where you were not born—there you will die.
verses.comment: Mother and son exiled together, showing how consequences of sin extend beyond the individual.

verses.text: But to the land to which they desire to return, there they will never return.
verses.comment: Permanent exclusion from the promised land echoes the spiritual consequences of final separation from communion.

verses.text: Is this man Coniah a despised, broken idol? Is he a vessel no one wants? Why are he and his descendants hurled out and cast into a land they do not know?
verses.comment: The imagery of the broken vessel aligns with later theological themes regarding the need for re-creation and restoration in God’s covenant people.

verses.text: O land, land, land, hear the word of the LORD!
verses.comment: Triple repetition signals urgency and universality—God’s message is for all creation. Prefigures the global scope of the Church.

verses.text: This is what the LORD says: Write this man down as childless, a man who will not prosper in his days; for none of his descendants will succeed in sitting on the throne of David or ruling anymore in Judah.
verses.comment: The prophecy effectively ends Coniah’s royal line, yet Matthew’s genealogy demonstrates God’s ability to transcend such judgments, culminating in Christ, the true heir of David’s throne.
